BE11:10am

UK prime minister Theresa May is stepping up efforts to win support from some Labour MPs for her Brexit deal ahead of next week’s vote by promising enhanced guarantees on environmental and workers’ rights.

Downing Street has indicated that the government could support an amendment laid down by a group of Labour MPs who are still tempted to back the withdrawal agreement.

As recently as October there were about 30 Labour MPs agonising over whether to support the Tory prime minister’s plan because they represent Leave-supporting constituencies and are afraid of a no-deal Brexit. By Christmas, the number had dwindled to a small handful amid concerns about the withdrawal agreement.

wayneJ And the Guardian had a great review: 'Jacob Rees-Mogg made a point that was only intelligible to him and was almost certainly incorrect'
BE11:10am

Every day we step closer to no deal.

wayneJ Apparently Mrs May hosted a 'charm offensive' at #10 last night. I am not entirely sure both those words go together.
Soundbuy 'loss of consumer confidence' ....................does this really mean 'folks shopped elsewhere.....
11:11 am
BE11:11am

Barclays Feltcollaredsource has, most conveniently, packaged up four soundbites for us on the latest developments. Here they are.

BE11:11am

Emmanuel Cau, Head of European Equity Strategy at Barclays, said:

“As seen throughout the past two-and-a-half years since the EU referendum, the fate of UK equities is dependent on the direction of GBP.”

“A rejection of the withdrawal agreement wouldn’t come as a shock to the markets.”

“Approval of the withdrawal agreement would be the most equity-friendly outcome and isn’t currently priced in.”

“If the withdrawal agreement passes, UK domestic equities and GBP could rally in tandem, as both are under-owned.”

“If rejected, we expect UK domestic plays to be hurt the most, while exporters should fare better. In June 2016, we saw exactly that; the FTSE250 underperformed while UK large caps in the FTSE100 fared better.”

Marvin Barth, Head of Global FX Strategy at Barclays, said:

“FX market pricing suggests that markets expect a failure of Parliament to pass the Withdrawal Agreement vote on 15 January by a relatively wide margin and that likely would lead to additional downside in GBP.

But they also show that EUR pricing does not well reflect these risks, suggesting that the negative reaction in EUR could be even greater. Passage of the Agreement would be a positive surprise that we would expect to lead to GBP gains.”

Henry Skeoch, Rates analyst at Barclays, said:

“Gilt yields are at broadly similar levels to at the time the Withdrawal Agreement vote was originally scheduled in December. The market expectation is likely still that the vote is unlikely to pass and the key will be what the next steps look like.”

“If the Withdrawal Agreement does unexpectedly pass, we would expect a broad-based sell-off in GBP rates and an increased chance of policy tightening being priced though the subdued domestic economic outlook should keep any sell-off contained.”

“We see the biggest potential impact in inflation markets: risks of a disorderly Brexit have kept breakevens on index-linked gilts and RPI swaps trading at a premium and should the Withdrawal Agreement pass, the market is likely to price in a far weaker inflation outlook than currently.”

Fabrice Montagne, Chief UK Economist at Barclays, said:

“Despite the uncertainty, we retain our view that the Withdrawal Agreement (WA) will eventually be ratified; however, we expect the timeline to be extended given that parliamentary mathematics suggest that PM May’s agreement will not be approved at the forthcoming House of Commons vote.”

VV75 Boris Johnson is rather Lord of the manor in a burning poop shed than a rent free tenant in a shiny castle.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

We see three key consequences of yesterday’s events: (1) The current withdrawal agreement is still unlikely to pass. Some anti-EU MPs could swing their support behind Theresa May’s deal if the no-deal route is closed off, but that is unlikely to constitute a majority without the DUP. (2) The government is unlikely to succeed in disabling parliamentary resistance via procedure, as the Speaker has demonstrated that he will make sure MPs get a say. So yesterday’s events close another avenue for the government to run down the clock towards ‘no-deal’. (3) The growing anti ‘no-deal’ majority suggests that Parliament could pull all the stops to prevent a chaotic exit from the EU. If MPs cannot force the government into a softer Brexit with amendments for an extension of Article 50 TEU, revocation, new negotiations, or a second referendum, or by blocking and amending other legislation, Parliament could withdraw confidence in the government and force new elections (or give confidence to an interim government to stop the Brexit clock). In sum, leaving (with or without a deal) on 29 March has become less likely, not leaving (for now) has become more likely.

What does it all mean? Other things equal, we expect Bloomberg consensus FY19E PBT to remain at c.£522mn (adj. EPS 25.0p, -11% yoy). This assumes -2% 2H18E UK LFL (C&H -1%, Food -3%), -25bp 2H18E UK gross margin delta (Food -50bp C&H +70bp), and flat yoy 2H19E opex.
Valuation: Our 260p DCF-derived 12-month price target implies a 10x FY19E EV/EBIT multiple (10.5x P/E).

BE11:24am

3Q Clothing & Home LFL -2.4% and total sales -4.8% (Citi -1.5%, -3.8%) — For the 13 week period to 29 December C&H LFL was -2.4% (Citi -1.5%) and space contribution was -2.4%, driving total 3Q sales -4.8% (Citi -3.8%). Online sales grew +14%, an acceleration of the c.+12%pts outperformance seen in 1H. Good October sales performance and better stock flow has reduced stock into sale by 25% yoy and to the lowest level in five years. International sales declined -1.4%, excluding impacts of businesses being exited.
 3Q Food LFL -2.1% (Citi -3.5%) and total sales -1.2% — Food 3Q LFL was -2.1% (Citi -3.5%) and space growth was +0.9%, driving total 3Q sales -1.2%. Commentary suggests that some volume growth has been driven through lower prices and less complex promotions. The majority of stores saw LFL growth over the Christmas period.
 FY19 guidance maintained — FY19 guidance remains unchanged: Food space increase c.flat, gross margin flat to -50bps. C&H space decrease c.-4%, gross margin flat to +50bps, UK opex +0-1% and capex £300-350m. FY results on 22 May.
 Implications — March 2019E PBT £521m to remain unchanged — Given the inline 3Q performance and unchanged guidance we expect current consensus PBT to remain unchanged. We have a £521m March 2019 PBT forecast (EPS 25.2p, -9.2% yoy). This assumes -2.8% UK FY19e sales, with Clothing & Home LFL sales of - 0.5% and Food LFL of -3.0%. On gross margins we forecast a -6bp decrease, with food gross margin -30bps and Clothing & Home +40bp. Coupled with cost decline of-1.4%, this drives UK trading profit of £465m, -13.2% yoy.
 Neutral, Target Price 290p — Our price target is 290p. This is based on MKS trading on an EV/EBIT multiple of c.10.5x to March-19. This equates to a 10.5x PE and is supported by a dividend yield of c.6%.

Tesco’s 3Q trading update (13 weeks to Nov 24th) came in in line with expectations with UK LFL at +0.7%. For the 6-week Christmas period, UK LFL beat consensus estimates by 110bps at +2.2%. Worth noting that 3Q was partly impacted by the launch of Tesco new PL ranges (almost complete) with an improving exit rate within the quarter. International was relatively weak but within expectations and an improving exit rate too. Importantly, management highlighted negotiations with suppliers concluding satisfactorily in Asia (reason for 1H miss) and reiterated FY expectations. Altogether the update should keep the shares re-rating,

BE11:32am

Tesco released its 3Q and Christmas sales this morning. UK LFL sales growth was +0.7% in 3Q and +2.2% over Christmas, compared with Bloomberg-collected consensus of +0.7% and +1.1% respectively. As we expected, Booker’s LFL sales slowed from the remarkable levels seen in 1H, but remained impressive at +10.7% in 3Q and +8.2% over Christmas (excluding tobacco). LFL sales in Asia slipped back in 3Q, but rebounded over Christmas to the least negative level since 4Q16/17 (-2.8%). We expect Tesco’s trading statement will be received very warmly because it addresses two of the key questions that arose in late 2018 and caused significant share price weakness – namely concerns around the strength of UK trading and also the profit shortfall that appeared in Thailand. Regarding UK trading, the statement shows a sharp rebound in UK LFL sales over Christmas compared with 3Q. Christmas is a very particular trading period and it can be dangerous to draw too many conclusions – but Tesco notes that its volumes were outperforming the market by the end of 3Q, helped by ‘Exclusively at Tesco’. Regarding the Thai situation, Tesco appears confident that it has made strong progress with its supplier discussions and it also highlights cost savings from changes made to its operating model. Overall Tesco notes its confidence in the outlook for the current financial year and states that it is “firmly on track” for the targets set out in October 2016 (of which the 3.5-4.0% margin target is most prominent). We reiterate our Overweight stock rating on Tesco (our Top Pick)

red not sure their products are in such demand, but also strategy they wanted to implement last may in training staff to personalise, ensure clients getting what they need. its a one off then further purchases done online where its cheaper
BE11:37am

Retail has seen LFLs fall -2.2% (motoring -3.4%, Cycling -0.3%) and a good outturn in autocentres of +1.4%. Retail motoring and cycling has been impacted by the sales of weather related products and both divisions were up against some decent comparatives. Good growth in services and maintenance word has helped drive an improvement in autocentres. Overall online sales grew 7.5% and represent 20% of total sales. However reflecting the impact on revenue of the mild weather and weak consumer confidence, leads to come chunky downgrades with guidance for FY19 underlying PBT now to fall in a range of £58m to £62m vs our current PBT estimate of £69.5m. Considering there remains the important Q4 period which for autocentres and retail motoring are three important months, moving towards the bottom end of the guided range seems appropriate. This suggests a 16.5% cut to numbers. We assume no PBT growth in FY20E. On the positive the Board is to maintain its dividend policy due to action on costs and support for FCF. Liberum view: Our view does not change and see Halfords as a high quality business with a more robust strategy as laid out by the new CEO, Graham Stapleton. The current valuation (CY19E PER less than 10x) is cheap and a dividend yield of greater than 6% is attractive compensation, in our view, while waiting for FY21E when sustainable profit growth resumes. Despite the downgrades today which are unfortunate, the profile of earnings to income has not changed.

BE11:37am

And Investec.

wayneJ Does anyone ever look at Costco in the context of UK supermarkets? Given the sales per store that Costco gets globally and how packed our local one is I do wonder if the spread of Costcos is also distorting supermarket sales?
Pharma @Finlay. Yes on Yvette Cooper - 70% leave I think.On voting for a deal, as someone who voted leave I would prefer remaining in the EU to May's deal. So not sure the deal on the table helps resolve anything.
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Q3 retail sales shortfall has resulted in an unscheduled update. Q3 (14
weeks) Retail sales fell -2.5%, with LFL sales down -2.2%. Unhelpfully, warm
weather meant disappointing Q3 weather-related car maintenance sales (LFL -
4.6%). Q3 is usually the most important quarter for this category. Against a very
strong comp (+7.8% LY), cycling sales were flat (LFL-0.3%), with growth in kids
bikes & accessories offset by decline in discretionary big ticket adult bikes.
Autocentres LFLs of + 1.4% was in-line with expectations. The underperformance
of car maintenance sales will also have a negative impact on gross margin mix.
Otherwise management reports tight gross margin and opex control.
 FY19e/FY20e PBT cut by 19%. In addition to Q3 sales shortfall, management
have understandably taken a more cautious short term view of Q4 given thwe
Brexit unknown, guiding to FY19 PBT in the range £58m-62m and kept previous
guidance of flat profits, FY20 on FY19. FY20 guidance may well prove too
conservative in our view given the needs-driven mature of much of HFD’s offer.
Management may have a clearer view at FY results in May.
 Still a strong cash generative model, with management expecting FCF in
FY19 to be up on FY18 and remaining confident that free cash flow will grow
over the medium term given good early progress in its cost and cash efficiency
programmes. Also, the Board is confident it can maintain its dividend policy.
 Valuation (CY19e PE 11.5x; 6.6% DPS yield) looks undemanding given the
strength of its robust cash generation and needs-driven nature of most of its
offer. Given the lack of profit progression for a number of years, Halfords is now
an income stock. Our TP, now based on a forecast DPS yield of 6%, falls to
300p, from 350p previously.

Here's Peel Hunt's Jonathan Prichard:

Flaneur This 'gearbox' resulted in a rough 'alliance' between Trump and the UAW union in the US recently. Strange bedfellows but a sign of the times...
Flaneur * 'gearbox famine'
BE11:45am

At first glance the Card Factory Xmas update looked solid enough, but the devil was in the outlook statement. Here management expressed that it did not expect to see any EBITDA growth next year, which essentially means that it thinks LFL will be flat and it will be difficult to mitigate the impacts of some cost headwinds. In general, we’ve got no problem with management teams being cautious right now, but value greetings cards are a defensive purchase and there shouldn’t be a macro reason for caution. The areas of cost inflation have been known for a while. So, we suspect that management sees a duller sales outlook than previously, which is disappointing given all the work that’s been done on the range, etc. Thus, the only attraction here is the yield, and whilst another special next year (5p) is probable, it’s not set in stone. There are similar yields available at companies with better immediate momentum, so we stick with REDUCE.

BE11:52am

We believe there is a high likelihood of the sustainability of the strong growth and hence the rerating of the Umicore stock from the company’s exposure to the electric vehicles (EV) market. This is due to: i) a longer and more stringent qualification process for new cathode material suppliers than our prior expectations; ii) 31% CAGR in cathode material demand from ‘17-25E for 8.8% EV penetration in ’25 with S/D balance likely to be favorable till 2021/22 at least; iii) operating leverage from significant volume growth is underestimated; and iv) significant battery recycling opportunity provides offset to the likely commoditization of the cathode material market in the long term. However, we see potential of a sizeable downside to 2019 consensus due to auto end demand weakness and also due to the fact that the phasing of the incremental volume growth in the cathode material business in 2019 could be lower than that reflected in consensus. Hence, while we remain a fan from mid- to long-term perspective, we believe the near term stock upside is likely to be capped, and thus downgrade the stock to Neutral.

We are incrementally more cautious around the Midway recovery with the latest UBS Evidence Lab customer review data showing a continued decline in average reviews across Midway, including among the key attractions. We now have greater concerns that this trend could be the result of poor investment or operational decisions, with cost cutting and a focus on new business development potentially leaving the core profit drivers of Midway under resourced. If our data is a leading indicator of site performance, it suggests further weakness in 2019. We reduce our forecasts by -6% for 2019E reflecting lower LFL growth expected in Midway and LEGOLAND, and downgrade to Sell after the stock's relative outperformance in 2018.

BE11:58am

The customer review data provides few positives for the Merlin Midway divisions; (1) average reviews across Midway declined from 4.06 to 4.0 y-o -y, and in 7 of the 10 brands; (2) the London Eye and Madam Tussauds London saw meaningful y-o -y average review declines in particular during H2; and (3) New brand Little BIG City is the third worst performing brand in the group for reviews. The performance of core London sites is of particular importance given they account for c.35% of profits but just 5% of sites. As such declining reviews and hence attendance could have a disproportionate effect on Midway profitability. We reduce our Midway LFL growth forecast I 2019E from 2% to 1%.
